standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply and extend previous understandings of division to divide unit fractions by whole numbers and whole numbers by unit fractions.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Divide fractions and whole numbers word problems

question.content: Billy has $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a kilogram of trail mix.  He wants to share it equally between himself and his brother.    **How much trail mix would they each get?**   kilogram

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \blueE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Billy has $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of a kilogram of trail mix. He plans to split the trail mix among $\blueE{2}$ people.  So, $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\blueE2$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of a kilogram is $1$ kilogram divided into $4$ equal pieces.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into four equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-fourth. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 kilogram.

hints.content: We can divide each $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$  piece into $\blueE2$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueE2$.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into four equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 2 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 2 parts are shaded purple. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 kilogram.

hints.content: $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\purpleE2=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$
Each person will get $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ of a kilogram of trail mix.

question.content: Jason has $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of a liter of milk. Jason divides the milk equally into $4$ mugs of tea.  **How much milk will Jason have in each mug?**   of a liter

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \blueE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Jason has $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ of a liter of milk. He plans to divide the milk into $\blueE{4}$ mugs.  So, $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\blueE4$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ of a liter is $1$ liter divided into $3$ equal pieces.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into three equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-third. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 liter.

hints.content: We can divide each $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{3}}$  piece into $\blueE4$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueE4$.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{12}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into three equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 4 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 4 parts are shaded purple. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 liter.

hints.content: $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\purpleE4=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{12}}$
Jason will have $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{12}}$ of a liter of milk in each of his mugs.

question.content: Mary used $\dfrac{1}{7}$ of a spool of ribbon to complete $4$ projects.  She used the same amount of ribbon on each project.   **How much ribbon did Mary use on each project?**   of a spool

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Mary has $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{7}}$ of a spool of ribbon. She used the ribbon equally across $\blueD{4}$ projects.  So, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{7}}\div\blueD4$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{7}}$ of a spool is $1$ spool divided into $7$ equal pieces.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into seven equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-seventh. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 spool.

hints.content: We can divide each $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{7}}$  piece into $\blueD4$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueD4$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{28}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into seven equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 4 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 4 parts are shaded green. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 spool.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{7}}\div\greenD4=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{28}}$
Mary used $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{28}}$ of a spool of ribbon on each project.

question.content: Lisa has $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of an hour to read and watch television.  She wants to split her time equally between the $2$ activities.    **How much time would she spend on each activity?**   of an hour

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Lisa has $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ of an hour. She wants to split this time across $\blueD{2}$ activities.  So, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\blueD2$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ of an hour is $1$ hour divided into $3$ equal pieces.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into three equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-third. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 hour.

hints.content: We can divide each $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$  piece into $\blueD2$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueD2$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into three equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 2 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 2 parts are shaded green. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 hour.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\greenD2=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$
Lisa will spend $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ of an hour on each activity.

question.content: Joe has $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a bag of peanuts.  He wants to share them equally among himself and $3$  friends.    **How much of the bag of peanuts would each person get?**   of the bag

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \blueE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Joe has $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ of a bag of peanuts. He wants to split the peanuts between $\blueE{4}$ people.  So, $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{2}}\div\blueE4$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ of a bag is $1$ bag divided into $2$ equal pieces.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into two equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-half. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 bag.

hints.content: We can divide each $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{2}}$  piece into $\blueE4$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueE4$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into two equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 4 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 4 parts are shaded purple. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 bag.

hints.content: $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{2}}\div\purpleE4=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$
Each person will get $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ of the bag of peanuts.

question.content: Amos is painting his pots. He needs $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a liter to paint all four pots.    **How much paint will he need for each of his $4$ pots if he uses the same amount of paint on each?**   of a liter

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \blueE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Amos has $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of a liter of paint. He wants to split the paint between $\blueE{4}$ pots.  So, $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\blueE4$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of a liter is $1$ liter divided into $4$ equal pieces.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into four equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-fourth. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 liter.

hints.content: We can divide each $\purpleE{\dfrac{1}{4}}$  piece into $\blueE4$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueE4$.  [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{16}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into four equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 4 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 4 parts are shaded purple. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 liter.

hints.content: $\blueE{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\purpleE4=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{16}}$
Amos needs  $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{16}}$ of a liter of paint for each of his pots.

question.content: Tommy will spend $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of his time this weekend studying for his $4$ final exams.    **What fraction of the weekend will he spend studying for each of his $4$ exams if he spends the same amount of time studying for each exam?**   of the weekend

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Tommy has $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ of his weekend to spend on exams. He wants to split his time between $\blueD{4}$ exams.  So, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{5}}\div\blueD4$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ of a weekend is $1$ weekend divided into $5$ equal pieces.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into five equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-fifth. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 weekend.

hints.content: We can divide each $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$  piece into $\blueD4$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueD4$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{20}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into five equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 4 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 4 parts are shaded green. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 weekend.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{5}}\div\greenD4=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{20}}$
Tommy will spend $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{20}}$ of the weekend studying for each of his final exams.

question.content: Andy painted at his house. He used $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of his paint to paint $5$ walls.    **What fraction of his paint did Andy use on each wall if he used the same amount of paint on each?**   of his paint

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Andy has $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of his paint to use on his walls. He wants to split his paint between $\blueD{5}$ walls.  So, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\blueD5$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ of Andy's paint is all of his paint divided into $4$ equal pieces.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into four equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-fourth. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled Andy's paint.

hints.content: We can divide each $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$  piece into $\blueD5$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueD5$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{20}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into four equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 5 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 5 parts are shaded green. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled Andy's paint.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\div\greenD5=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{20}}$
Andy used  $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{20}}$ of his paint on each wall.

question.content: Sara decides to bottle $\dfrac{1}{3}$ of her milk.  She pours the milk evenly among $5$ bottles.   **What fraction of her milk will she put in each bottle$?$**   of her milk

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Sara has $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ of her milk to bottle. She wants to split this milk between $\blueD{5}$ bottles.  So, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\blueD5$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$ of Sara's milk is all of her milk divided into $3$ equal pieces.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into three equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-third. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled Sara's milk.

hints.content: We can divide each $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{3}}$  piece into $\blueD5$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueD5$.     [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{15}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into three equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 5 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 5 parts are shaded green. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled Sara's milk.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\div\greenD5=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{15}}$
Sara will put $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{15}}$ of her milk in each bottle.

question.content: Paris has decided to give $\dfrac{1}{8}$ of her perfume to her $3$ closest friends.   **What fraction of the perfume will she give to each of her $3$ friends if she gives each of them the same amount of perfume?**   of her perfume

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Paris has $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ of her perfume to share. She wants to split this perfume between $\blueD{3}$ friends.  So, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{8}}\div\blueD3$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$ of Paris's perfume is all of her perfume divided into $8$ equal pieces.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into eight equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-eighth. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled Paris's perfume.

hints.content: We can divide each $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{8}}$  piece into $\blueD3$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueD3$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{24}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into eight equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 3 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 3 parts are shaded green. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled Paris's perfume.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{8}}\div\greenD3=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{24}}$
Paris will give each of her friends $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{24}}$ of her perfume.

question.content: Susan has $\dfrac{1}{6}$ of a bottle of water.  She wants to share it equally among herself and $2$  friends.    **What fraction of the bottle of water would each person get?**   of a bottle

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Susan has $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ of her bottle of water to share. She wants to split her bottle between $\blueD{3}$ people.  So, $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{6}}\div\blueD3$ will give us our answer.
We know that $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$ of the bottle of water is $1$ bottle of water divided into $6$ equal pieces.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into six equal-size parts. Each part is labeled one-sixth. One part is shaded. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 bottle.

hints.content: We can divide each $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{6}}$  piece into $\blueD3$ equal pieces to show division by $\blueD3$.    [[☃ image 1]]  Each of these new smaller pieces is equal $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{18}}$.

images.alt: A square divided into 6 equal-size parts. Each part is further divided into 3 smaller, equal-sized parts. The left 3 parts are shaded green. The top, left part is striped and labeled question mark. Across the square is a curved bracket labeled 1 bottle.

hints.content: $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{6}}\div\greenD3=\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{18}}$
Each person will get $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{18}}$ of the bottle of water.

question.content: Matt is filling containers of rice.  Each container holds $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a kilogram of rice.    **If Matt has $7$ kilograms of rice, how many containers can he fill?**   containers

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Matt has $\greenD7$ total kilograms of rice. Each container holds $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ kg of rice.  So, $\greenD7\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ will give us our answer.
Let's use these $\greenD7$ rectangles to represent the $\greenD7$ kilograms of rice.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 3 rectangles in the second row.

hints.content: Since each container holds $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ of a kilogram, we  divide each of the $\greenD7$ kilograms of rice into $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ kilogram portions.   [[☃ image 1]]      How many $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ kilogram portions of rice are there?

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 3 rectangles in the second row. Each rectangle is divided into 4 equal-sized parts. Each part is shaded and labeled one-fourth.

hints.content: There are $\blueD{28}$ portions of $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ kilogram of rice.  $\greenD7\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}=\blueD{28}$
Matt can fill $\blueD{28}$ containers.

question.content: Priscilla has some grapes that she wants to give to her friends.  She wants to give $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a kilogram of grapes to each friend.    **If Priscilla has $6$ kilograms of grapes, to how many friends can she give grapes?**   friends

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Priscilla has $\greenD6$ total kilograms of grapes. Each friend will get $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ kg of grapes.  So, $\greenD6\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ will give us our answer.
Let's use these $\greenD6$ rectangles to represent the $\greenD6$ kilograms of grapes.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 2 rectangles in the second row.

hints.content: Since each friend will get $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ of a kilogram, we divide each of the $\greenD6$ kilograms of grapes into $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ kilogram portions.  [[☃ image 1]]      How many $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ kilogram portions of grapes are there?

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 2 rectangles in the second row. Each rectangle is divided into 4 equal-sized parts. Each part is shaded and labeled one-fourth.

hints.content: There are $\blueD{24}$ portions of $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ kilogram of grapes.  $\greenD6\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}=\blueD{24}$
Priscilla can share with $\blueD{24}$ friends.

question.content: Sally has been measuring a flower for a science project.  The flower has grown $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a centimeter each day and grown a total of $2$ centimeters taller.    **How many days has Sally been measuring this flower?**   days

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \blueE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
The flower has grown $\purpleE2$ total centimeters taller. Each day, the flower grew by $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ centimeters.  So, $\purpleE2\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ will give us our answer.
Let's use these $\purpleE2$ rectangles to represent the $\purpleE2$ centimeters grown.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A row of two equal-sized rectangles.

hints.content: Since each day the flower grew by $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ of a centimeter, we divide each of the $\purpleE2$ centimers grown into $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ centimeter portions.  [[☃ image 1]]  How many $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ centimeter portions are there?

images.alt: A row of two equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into 2 equal-sized parts. Each part is shaded and labeled one-half.

hints.content: There are $\blueE{4}$ portions of $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ centimeters of growth.  $\purpleE2\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\blueE{4}$
Sally has been measuring the flower for $\blueE{4}$ days.

question.content: Bethany has some coffee that she wants to give to her friends.  She wants to give $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a liter of coffee to each friend.    **If Bethany has $6$ liters of coffee to give to her friends, how many friends can she share her coffee with?**   friends

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \blueE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Bethany has $\purpleE6$ total liters of coffee. Each friend will get $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ of a liter of coffee.  So, $\purpleE6\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ will give us our answer.
Let's use these $\purpleE6$ rectangles to represent the $\purpleE6$ liters of coffee.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 2 rectangles in the second row.

hints.content: Since each friend will get $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ of a liter, we  divide each of the $\purpleE6$ liters of coffee into $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ liter portions.  [[☃ image 1]]  How many $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ liter portions of coffee are there?

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 2 rectangles in the second row. Each rectangle is divided into 2 equal-sized parts. Each part is shaded and labeled one-half.

hints.content: There are $\blueE{12}$ portions of $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ of a liter of coffee.  $\purpleE6\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\blueE{12}$
Bethany can share her coffee with $\blueE{12}$ friends.

question.content: Mrs. Amy has $5$ bunches of grapes, which she is serving as a snack to a group of children. Each serving is $\dfrac{1}{4}$ of a bunch.    **How many children can get a serving of grapes as a snack?**   children

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:  $\begin{align} \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \blueE{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \purpleE{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueE{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Mrs. Amy has $\purpleE5$ total bunches of grapes. Each child will get $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ of a bunch of grapes.  So, $\purpleE5\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ will give us our answer.
Let's use these $\purpleE5$ rectangles to represent the $\purpleE5$ bunches of grapes.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 1 rectangle in the second row.

hints.content: Since each child will get $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ of a bunch, we  divide each of the $\purpleE5$ bunches of grapes into $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ bunch portions.  [[☃ image 1]]  How many $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ bunch portions of grapes are there?

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 1 rectangle in the second row. Each rectangle is divided into 4 equal-sized parts. Each part is shaded and labeled one-fourth.

hints.content: There are $\blueE{20}$ portions of $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ of a bunch of grapes.  $\purpleE5\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{4}}=\blueE{20}$
Mrs. Amy can give grapes to $\blueE{20}$ children.

question.content: Leah decided to paint some of the rooms at her $51$-room hotel. She needs $\dfrac{1}{5}$ of a can of paint per room.    **If Leah had $6$ cans of paint, how many rooms can she paint?**   rooms

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Leah has $\greenD6$ cans of paint. Each room will get $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$ of a can of paint.  So, $\greenD6\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ will give us our answer.
Let's use these $\greenD6$ rectangles to represent the $\greenD6$ cans of paint.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 2 rectangles in the second row.

hints.content: Since each room will get $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$ of a can, we  divide each of the $\greenD6$ cans of paint into $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$ can portions.  [[☃ image 1]]    How many $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$ can portions of paint are there?

images.alt: Two rows of equal-sized rectangles. There are 4 rectangles in the first row and 2 rectangles in the second row. Each rectangle is divided into 5 equal-sized parts. Each part is shaded and labeled one-fifth.

hints.content: There are $\blueD{30}$ portions of $\maroonD{\dfrac15}$ can of paint.  $\greenD6\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{5}}=\blueD{30}$
Leah can paint $\blueD{30}$ rooms.

question.content: Jamie is painting her house.  Each room takes $\dfrac{1}{2}$ of a liter of paint.    **If Jamie has $3$ liters of paint, how many rooms can she paint?**   rooms

hints.content: We can think of division as the following:   $\begin{align} \greenD{\text{total}} \div \blueD{\text{number of groups}} =\maroonD{\text{size of groups}} \\\\ \greenD{\text{total}} \div \maroonD{\text{size of groups}} =\blueD{\text{number of groups}} \end{align}$
Jamie has $\greenD3$ liters of paint. Each room will get $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ of a liter of paint.  So, $\greenD3\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$ will give us our answer.
Let's use these $\greenD3$ rectangles to represent the $\greenD3$ liters of paint.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A row of three equal-sized rectangles.

hints.content: Since each room will get $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ of a liter, we  divide each of the $\greenD3$ liters of paint into $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ liter portions.   [[☃ image 1]]    How many $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ liter portions of paint are there?

images.alt: A row of three equal-sized rectangles. Each rectangle is divided into 2 equal-sized parts. Each part is shaded and labeled one-half.

hints.content: There are $\blueD{6}$ portions of $\maroonD{\dfrac12}$ liter of paint.  $\greenD3\div\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}=\blueD{6}$
Jamie can paint $\blueD{6}$ rooms.
